definition: prefix used before the surname of a person or a numeral indicating the order of birth of the children in a family or to indicate affection or familiarity/old (of people)/venerable (person)/experienced/of long standing/always/all the time/of the past/very/outdated/(of meat etc) tough
sb or sth detested by all/target of scorn/anathema/cf. 老鼠過街，人人喊打|老鼠过街，人人喊打[lao3 shu3 guo4 jie1 , ren2 ren2 han3 da3]
the cat weeps for the dead mouse (idiom); hypocritical pretence of condolence/crocodile tears
lit. a piece of rat feces spoiled the whole pot of congee (idiom)/fig. one bad apple can spoil the whole bunch
pinyin: yi1 li4 lao3 shu3 shi3 huai4 le5 yi1 guo1 zhou1
containing_words.word: 一粒老鼠屎坏了一锅粥

definition: lit. a piece of rat feces spoiled the whole pot of soup (idiom)/fig. one bad apple can spoil the whole bunch
pinyin: yi1 ke1 lao3 shu3 shi3 huai4 le5 yi1 guo1 tang1
containing_words.word: 一颗老鼠屎坏了一锅汤

definition: see 一粒老鼠屎壞了一鍋粥|一粒老鼠屎坏了一锅粥[yi1 li4 lao3 shu3 shi3 huai4 le5 yi1 guo1 zhou1]
pinyin: yi1 ke1 lao3 shu3 shi3 huai4 le5 yi1 guo1 zhou1
containing_words.word: 一颗老鼠屎坏了一锅粥

definition: it doesn't matter whether a cat is white or black; as long as it catches mice it's a good cat (variant of a Sichuanese saying used in a speech by Deng Xiaoping 鄧小平|邓小平[Deng4 Xiao3 ping2] in 1962, usually associated with his economic reforms starting in 1978, in which pragmatism was favored over ideological purity)
pinyin: bu4 guan3 bai2 mao1 hei1 mao1 , zhuo1 zhu4 lao3 shu3 jiu4 shi4 hao3 mao1
containing_words.word: 不管白猫黑猫，捉住老鼠就是好猫

definition: lit. a dog who catches mice (idiom)/fig. to be meddlesome
lit. rat's tail; fig. a follower of inferior stature
like mice trying to pull a turtle, nowhere to get a hand grip (idiom)/no clue where to start
pinyin: lao3 shu3 la1 gui1 , wu2 cong2 xia4 shou3

definition: when the mice drag a shovel, the biggest thing comes second/the tip of the iceberg/the cockroach principle
pinyin: lao3 shu3 tuo1 mu4 xian1 , da4 tou2 zai4 hou4 tou5
containing_words.word: 老鼠拖木锨，大头在后头

definition: lit. when a rat crosses the street, people chase it down (idiom)/fig. everyone detests a lowlife
pinyin: lao3 shu3 guo4 jie1 , ren2 ren2 han3 da3

sentences.english: It is a bold mouse that nestles in cat's ear.
sentences.chinese: 再胆大的老鼠也不敢在猫耳朵里做窝。

sentences.english: The owl swooped down on a mouse.
sentences.chinese: 猫头鹰向一只老鼠飞扑过去。
那些小老鼠也都爬开了。

sentences.english: They continue their cat-and-mouse game for a seemingly inter-minable period of time.
sentences.chinese: 他们似乎没完没了地玩着这个猫捉老鼠的游戏。

sentences.english: Yes, only a rat puppet beat them out.
sentences.chinese: 没错，只有一个老鼠木偶打败过他们。

sentences.english: Not through the mousehole this time, he told himself.
sentences.chinese: 安德对自己说，这次不去老鼠洞。

sentences.english: The cat darted at the mouse.
sentences.chinese: 这只猫朝那只老鼠窜了过去。

sentences.english: 99 percent of lawyers give the rest a bad name.
sentences.chinese: 百分之九十九的律师是毁坏律师界名声的大老鼠。

sentences.english: Some of the cells in the resultant mouse will contain the inactivated gene.
sentences.chinese: 最终老鼠的某些细胞中将含有灭活基因。

sentences.english: It's a bold mouse that nestles in the cat's ear.
sentences.chinese: 再胆大的老鼠也不敢在猫耳朵里做窝。

sentences.english: The Chinese Hamster belongs to a group known as Rat-like hamsters.
sentences.chinese: 相比之下，中华仓鼠是和老鼠更为相似的一种仓鼠。

sentences.english: Mice and many other animals have both of these characteristics, and humans do not.
sentences.chinese: 老鼠和许多其他动物都有这两个特性，但是人类没有。

sentences.english: The cat is playing with a live mouse.
sentences.chinese: 猫在把玩簸弄那只活老鼠。

sentences.english: The children are playing what they call "cat-and-rat".
sentences.chinese: 孩子们在玩“猫抓老鼠”的游戏。

sentences.english: No doubt, you can turn us into creatures like rats in that way.
sentences.chinese: 无疑人类可以被变成老鼠般的生物。

sentences.english: Pasch says it's mostly males that sing.
sentences.chinese: 派斯克说“歌唱”的老鼠大多数都是雄鼠。
